img.alt: Dash: Open data for the global research community
img.title: Dash: Open data for the global research community

div.div:
Dash is a service of the University of California Curation Center of the California Digital Library.
Copyright © 2014 The Regents of the University of California

Dash is a collaborative project between the
UC Libraries and the UC Curation Center.

div.h2: Who can deposit data into Dash?
div.p: Researchers from University of California partner campuses can use their campus credentials to deposit data into their campus instance of Dash (see the list of campus partners). Researchers from outside of the UC or from non-partner campuses can use Google credentials to deposit data via DataONE Dash.
div.h2: What is the relationship between DataONE Dash, ONEShare, and UC Dash?
div.p: Dash is public online service for curating research data supported by the California Digital Library (CDL). There are two versions of Dash: 1) UC Dash and 2) DataONE Dash. UC Dash is targeted for use by the 10 University of California campuses. DataONE Dash is a separate service, operated by CDL in collaboration with the DataONE project, that is open to the non-UC research community. ONEShare is the name of the curation repository underlying DataONE Dash.
div.h2: Who can access datasets in Dash?
div.p: Data submitted to DataONE Dash are in the public domain under a Creative Commons Universal waiver (CC0); there are no restrictions on use, reuse, or repurposing the data.

Data submitted to UC Dash are released under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution license (CC-BY-4.0). This means anyone can access the datasets, download them, and use them provided they give proper attribution.

Although many researchers would prefer to maintain more control over who downloads and uses their data, we believe that having data that are fully open is the best way to enable academic advancement. Read the Panton Principles for Open Data in Science for more information.
div.h2: Do you support data embargoes or restricted access?
div.p: Not at this time. We do, however, have plans to expand the Dash functionality to include both. If you have specific requests for functionality, please add it to our GitHub Issues page.
div.h2: What do I need to submit the data?

ul.li: Permission from the appropriate PI(s)
Information about the dataset, including dataset title, authors, keywords, and an abstract
Access to files comprising the data set

div.h2: Are there any file format requirements?
div.p: No. Files of any type are acceptable for deposit. Ideally, file types will be non-proprietary. If you have files of a specialized or proprietary nature, be sure they are accompanied by any pertinent information that would allow the proper viewing and/or usage of the file. This information could be stored in the "Methods" section of the metadata, or as a separate "Readme" document archived alongside the dataset files.
div.h2: What best practices can I follow for data preparation?
div.p: There are a variety of best practices depending on your field of research. For generic help, see the DataONE Primer on Data Management Best Practices (PDF). Generally,

ul.li: Ensure data files are the most up-to-date and complete versions
Ensure the integrity of data files (check if corrupted)
Ensure that all data relating to human subjects has been properly de-identified
Double-check the accuracy of the descriptive metadata
Enter as much descriptive metadata as possible in the indexing fields
Ensure that any information critical to the proper viewing and/or usage of the data is included in the submission (e.g., as a separate "Readme" file)

div.h2: For how long will the data be available?
div.p: Once you have deposited data, it is permanently archived and available through the California Digital Library's Merritt Repository. See our Policies page for more information.
Yes, you can add new versions of your data.
div.h2: How will someone find my data?
div.p: Metadata will be indexed by the Thomson-Reuters Data Citation Index and Scopus. All datasets in Dash are given a unique Digital Object Identifier or DOI. Entering the DOI URL in any browser will take the user to the dataset's landing page in Dash. Dash also provides a faceted search and browse capability for direct discovery.
div.h2: Do the data have to be associated with a publication?
div.p: No. Dash accepts all quality data, regardless of whether they have been used to publish a paper.
div.h2: Do I need to log into Dash to get data?
div.p: Persons requesting data are not required to sign-in in order to do so.
div.h2: Do I have to pay for data?
div.p: No, these data are made publicly available free of charge.
div.h2: What if I have questions about the data?
div.p: Please contact us with any questions about the data.

about.p: Dash is a new self-service tool for researchers to describe, upload, and share their research data. It is designed to be a simple self-service curation tool for researchers, and helps them perform the following tasks:

ul.li: Prepare data for curation by reviewing best practice guidance for the creation or acquisition of digital research data.
Select data for curation through local file browse or drag-and-drop operation.
Describe data in terms of the DataCite metadata schema.
Identify data with a persistent digital object identifier (DOI) for permanent citation and discovery.
Preserve, manage, and share data by uploading to a public Merritt repository collection.
Discover and retrieve data through faceted search and browse.

about.h2: There are two versions of Dash: UC Dash and DataONE Dash
about.p: UC Dash is targeted for use by the 10 University of California campuses. There are currently five live instances of UC Dash:

DataONE Dash is a separate service, operated by CDL in collaboration with the DataONE project, that is open to the non-UC research community. ONEShare is the name of the curation repository underlying DataONE Dash.

ul.li: Read more about the code, the project, and contributing to development on the Dash GitHub site
Log enhancements or bugs on the Dash GitHub Issues page
Check out our Dash Facebook, Google+ and Twitter accounts.
Read about our Site Descriptors project to develop a way to cite research stations.
Check out the Data Pub blog for updates and data news.
Read our funded proposal to the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation to improve the Dash interface and functionality.

about.p: Data sharing is critical for the advancement of knowledge. Researchers benefit from increased collaborations, validation and recognition of their work; institutions and funders benefit from the measurable increase in the impact of their resources; and society benefits from the faster pace at which research can progress. There are several barriers to providing access to data, and currently data sharing is mostly done by large, well funded multi-investigator projects. If these barriers were addressed, allowing individual investigators to easily and quickly share their primary research data, we could create a new culture of transparency and efficiency—likely resulting in major impacts on knowledge advancement.
UC Dash is a collaborative project between the UC Libraries and the UC Curation Center (UC3) at the California Digital Library.
